Without saying too much, he has an insider's story to tell - about how the tobacco companies manipulate nicotine to make it more addictive and how he knows the "Seven Dwarves" (Wigand's term for the executives of the main seven tobacco companies) lied in their testimony to Congress.Al Pacino's character, Lowell Bergman, is a producer for 60 Minutes who wants his show to be the public conduit for Wigand's information. The film chronicles how difficult it is to publicize this damaging information not just because of retaliation by the the tobacco companies but by CBS's unwillingness to stick it's neck out on a vital public health issue.Crowe is marvelous - he effectively conveys the emotions of a tormented man, yet he never becomes a characture. Wigand is intelligent and wants to protect his family, and that never changes despite the odds. Al Pacino is excellent as usual - he convincingly portrays Bergman's dogmatic pursuit of truth and his high standard of never leaving a source hanging out to dry. The suspension of disbelief took over quickly for me. Early on, I stopped looking at Pacino and Crowe as Pacino and Crowe - they were Bergman and Wigand to me.This film affected me much in the same way "Quiz Show" did. Both films are in ways about "the end of innocence" by selling out principles to the almighty dollar. One convicting scene involves Bergman battling CBS legal department over the story. The gist of the lawyer's position is simply this: the more truth you tell, the more liable CBS is. If that's not twisted, I don't know what is.This movie should get you thinking about a variety of issues: what is a corporation's responsibility to the public well-being? Does corporate ownership of the media compromise what is reported? Is it worth all the personal sacrifices to make certain information public? If you're not thinking about larger issues after watching this film, you simply weren't paying attention.My rating: 9 out of a possible 10

reviews.review_title: More than a modern All the President's Men
reviews.content: The sense of scandal and coverup is in the air of this film, just like the political thrillers of the 1970s. I was truly impressed at the amount of drama and suspense that was packed into this story, even though some of it is fictional. The performances are outstanding, too. Everyone is singing praises for Russell Crowe, and with good reason. The ones that really blew me away, though, were Al Pacino and Christopher Plummer. Director Michael Mann also snuck some clever camera work and beautiful photography in. The only problem I had with the film was that some of the camera work was unprofessionally shaky. Other than that, though, I can just about guarantee this film will surprise you with its depth. It's one of the year's five best.

reviews.review_title: Excellent cinematography and music elevate a tedious story
reviews.content: In order to do justice to an actual event either in a book or in a film, it usually helps to allow adequate time to pass between the event itself and the retelling of the event.  This allows authors, filmmakers, etc. time to assess the social, political, and/or historical significance of the incident and tell the story with this in mind.  Unfortunately, the controversy in Mann's -The Insider- occurred only four years ago and the true, perhaps indelible impact Wigand's story had on the tobacco industry, on investigative journalism, and on America as a whole has yet to be felt.Mann's movie certainly details a provocative--sometimes infuriating--incident, however the film entertains without providing much analysis or insight about WHY Wigand's saga is important.  At over two hours, the story failed to keep my attention.  The film's saving graces are solid performances by Russell Crowe, Christopher Plummer, and Al Pacino; beautiful, moody cinematography; and an excellent score which includes classical pieces, opera, and fluid, ambient synthesized music.

This movie was outstanding.  Mr. Pacino's performance was definitely oscar caliber and very brilliant.  Mr. Crowe's performance is what oscar nominations are made of and Mr Crowe gives the best performance of his career.  I want to also thank Mr. Mann for his superb direction of this movie which made it very enjoyable and compelling.  Mr. Mann's movie is a masterpiece and definitely has oscar nominations written all over it.  I rate this movie ***** (5 stars).

Once in many years you get to have a combination of a great story with a perfect acting, directing and music. 2 hours and 35 minutes of breathtaking cinema. god bless all the people who were involved in creating this masterpiece. bring on the Oscar!

reviews.review_title: A tale of truth which slowly emerges.
reviews.content: It is a rare pleasure to witness on screen a film which not only is enjoyable to watch but will also leave you with a sense of darkness, sorrow and regret.Strong dialogue and even stronger emotions are displayed by Al Pacino's "live on the edge" character Lowell Bergman and Russel Crowe's whistle-blowing Jeffrey Wigand will leave you saddened and hooked whilst the remainder of the cast give the performances of their lives.It's a tale of truth which slowly emerges whilst a character's faith quickly falls. A true masterpiece if ever there was one.

This is Michael Mann's best movie, I enjoyed Heat a lot but this movie was even better. Personally I think this movie was better then American beauty which was a great film. Michael Mann's visual style was wonderful and the acting was great but Crowe and Pachino. The year 1999 had some really great movies. I wish 2001 would have have as many good ones.

Anyone who believes Russell Crowe gave a ghastly performance in this film is kidding themselves ie So Near, And Yet So Far...I watched a documentary on the weekend featuring the real life Jeffrey Wigand. After seeing this, i decided to watch The Insider again and was blown away by how well Crowe nailed his look and mannerisms. To suggest the non American casting of Crowe destroyed the film is laughable. Geez, be proud of your country but don't get so caught up in patriotism to think that only American actors should be cast in such roles.Crowe is a masterful actor, giving five performances (Romper stomper, LA Confidential, The Insider, Gladiator, and A Beautiful Mind) that any actor would be proud to have on their resume.

This could have been a really terrific movie.  The acting was amazing and the story was well written.  Unfortunately Michael Mann's direction was awful.  I'm not quite sure what happened, since he did such a good job with "Heat."  In "The Insider" he constantly uses awkward focusing techniques and hand-held cameras- it's like watching "The Blair Witch Project" but worse because you're trying to follow a complex plot, but people's heads keep shifting in and out of focus, and the camera keeps zooming around in blurry close-ups, that I got dizzy every scene.  The movie was too long at almost 3 hours, it could have easily had 30 minutes or so cut. The problem is I really liked this movie.  I was looking forward to it, Mann's awkward direction and often out-of-place music cues detracted a lot from this film- I can only honestly give it ** out of **** stars.  Its a real shame, this could have been an incredible movie.  Pacino, Crowe, and especially Christopher Plummer were fantastic.  Really unfortunate.

What a great film.  Michael Mann, who usually directs action films, brings his guns 'n glory gusto to this movie, the story of a tobacco company insider who wants to go public with his knowledge.  All the performances are wonderful, but a particular standout is Russell Crowe as the whistle-blower in question.  His work is first-rate.  Another winner from Michael Mann!

I thought the movie made very good drama out of a story that might of otherwise been rather dull (I am not a follower of the smoking industry scandal). Fine performances all around, but particularly by Russell Crowe. I would only dispute some of the directional choices with respect to what I would say was dramatic effect over charaterization.For example, the extreme closeups and the soundtrack (much as I enjoy that kind of music) often made me wonder when someone was about to get shot; impending danger, yes, impending extreme violence, a slight overstatement, no? Additionally, I think a few corners had been cut in the characterizations of some of the important supporting roles such as Liane Wigand, and Mike Wallace. I felt the former's exit from the marriage seemed premature relative to immediate context of the narrative; similarly, Wallace's decision to side with CBS Corporate seemed to come out of left field. I believe in both cases the story could have foreshadowed a little better the capacity for the characters to eventually make the decisions that they did (the restaurant meeting scene wasn't enough to me). Instead, we saw extensive footage given to the opening Iranian sequences, the Unibomber sequences, though plotwise their relation to rest of the story was rather inconsequential.Moreover, I felt that the film towards the end dropped the development of who I thought was the protagonist, Wigand, to concentrate solely on Lowell Bergman's heroism. I think I would have like to see more of Wigand as 'survivor'.These points downgraded the film's quality for me, though on the whole, very good!

I was not really in the mood to see this movie.  We argued over whether to see this or The Bone Collector and I'm glad my companion won!
Al Pacino has been wearing on my nerves in his latest endeavors and I really didn't feel like sitting through another one of his acting tirades. Imagine my delight when I found his character and his acting to be sensational. Christopher Plummer was another standout in this cast and Russell Crowe was fantastic. My only dilemma now is whether Pacino or Kevin Spacey should be up for the best actor academy award!The story moves quickly and thank goodness for that due to it's length, the only time I checked my watch was to see if the end was near or I could enjoy more of this.I've decided I must be a Michael Mann fan because I loved this movie and Heat.  I can only name a handful of movies where the soundtrack has been noticeable and this was definitely one of them.I'm not the type that checks out camera angles and other subtleties, I just like to get some bounce for my buck and this movie certainly delivers.

Best movie of '99. Probably, of the last 5 years, and very possibly, of the decade. Brilliant direction. Rich, powerful performances. Intelligent, literate and realistic screenplay. Beautiful cinematography. Go see this film. Then go see it again!

reviews.review_title: Oh no, what a boring boring movie...
reviews.content: Whoever came up with the idea to make a movie about that guy from Romper Stomper, now with bleached hair, who confesses to 60 minutes that he put ammonia in cigarettes for some tobacco company should never make movies again. There is absolutely no action in this flick, no comedy, nothing! Nothing happens in the whole movie. All it shows is how unjust american law is.  Basically the whole movie would be summed up into a 10 minute documentary, and we wouldn't waste 3 hours of our lives watching it. Not only that, but it was in widescreen so everything appeared so small and half the time I had no clue what going on.  The dialogue is also difficult to understand.I give this 1 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: The most engrossing, clever film of 1999
reviews.content: The Insider is based on the true story of two men who fight to get public information out to the public. Lowell Bergman (Pacino) is a producer of 60 Minutes. Jeff Wigand (Crowe) is an ex-executive at Brown and Williamson (America's 3rd largest tobacco company). When Bergman approaches Wigand to be a consultant on a fire safety study on cigarrettes Brown and Williamson blackmail him into furthering his confidentiality agreement. Bergman can tell that Wigand has something to say but can't. So he sets up Wigand to testify in a court of public opinion on behalf of the state of Mississipi. He does, and he also does a CBS interview on 60 Minutes with Mike Wallace (Plummer). The information is simple. That the tobacco industry has been lying to the people about nicotine. That it is not only addictive but they also manipulate it to increase its addictiveness. But big tobacco are trying to do all they can to shut Wigand up. They use restraining orders, they treating CBS with a lawsuit and they start a smear campaign against Wigand. All these things separate Wigand from his family and Bergman from the rest of CBS. This was a fantastic movie. It deserved all 7 of the Oscars it was nominated for. Michael Mann's direction is impeccable as he shows what the people are thinking and the emotions they are feeling. The film is long but very engrossing. The film switches half-way through from Wigand giving the information to Bergman fighting to air the information. Al Pacino shows that he is one of the best actors in Hollywood with an Oscar worthy performance. But the star of the show was Russell Crowe as Jeff Wigand. His performance is perfect as a man torn between what is right and what is best for his family and he stops short of showing Wigand to be a persecuted hero, but as a man whose whole life is threatened by what he knows. Out of 10 i will give this film 9.5

I really enjoyed this film.  I thought that Russell Crowe was absolutely entertaining,brilliant and great at this movie.  He should have won the Academy Award however he did win the Golden Globe.  The story was uplifting and interesting.  The cast and crew knew what they were doing when they decided to make this film.  I loved it because the acting was very good. The only thing negative that I can say about The Insider is the length. Otherwise it was great.  Russell  Crowe was extremely believable and understandable.  Thanks,Suzanne

Simply one of the best movies of the past 5-10 years. I left the theater thinking "that is what a movie can be!"Well acted, top to bottom, with masterful direction and writing by Mann. Most inspiring is Mann's willingness to use SILENCE, a concept lost to almost every director in the post-sound era. Music is added when necessary (as is dialogue, of course) but Mann lets the gaps do much of the work, to great effect.Pacino, brilliant as always, using a bit of his Ricky Roma salesman character, tempered with the heart of an idealist. Academy Award should go to Crowe, however, who turns in a career-making performance. Rest of cast strong in support.

I can understand why the validity of the truth behind this film might be questioned.  However, you have to realize that you have to see this movie for what it is:  A powerful story about strength, hope and how an individual can overcome REALISTIC, overwhelming odds.  Ironically enough, another film like this one was also overlooked by the academy, whose characters used hope and strength to survive more life-threatening situations: "The Shawshank Redemption".From the movie's excellent direction (a superior ability to make a thriller without action and still maintain the quick pace), wonderful screenplay,haunting musical score and especially the fantastic acting) will be a film to be remembered for a long time.The acting is incredible.  Plummer's performance as Mike Wallace is frightenly real.  Pacino finally gave up his screaming method-acting he picked up in "Scent of a Woman" and gave a subtle, energetic portrayal that is his best in years.But the actor who gives the movie its heart is Crowe's Wigand.  His is a performance that shows realistic struggles of what this man is going through and what he loses.  And when he does get his emotional battle scars, he maintains his silent composure, but reveals his pain through his eyes. His is the best portrayal of "an ordinary man facing an overwhelming circumstance" and should be an example of how to face our problems like a fighter, not a victim.I was extremely disappointed that he did not win for best actor.  Although I am a Kevin Spacey fan,  Crowe's was the most multi-layered, and the transformation was more thorough.  Unfortunately,  for the last 3 years, the academy has been blatantly showing that it's not the best performance that wins, but who is the most popular.  3 years ago, it was Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt who won for "As Good As it Gets", instead of Judi Dench for "Mrs. Brown" and Peter Fonda for "Ulee's Gold" (or Robert Duvall for "Apostle").  Then, 2 years ago: Gwyneth Paltrow for "Shakespeare in Love" and Roberto Benigni for "Life is Beautiful" instead of Cate Blanchette for "Elizabeth" and Nick Nolte for "Affliction" or Ian McKellan for "Gods and Monsters".  Now, Kevin Spacey came out of the blue for "American Beauty", based on this popularity.  The only redeeming factor was Swank winning for "Boys Don't Cry".Again, I'm a fan of Spacey's, but Crowe, as well as many others in this film, were robbed of the recognition they deserved. Perhaps the inspiration that is generated from the film to the viewer is good enough.

There are times that The Insider will leave you breathless. The story about tobacco-industry scientist Jeffrey Wigland's tormented decision to blow the whistle. It's a story that needed to be told, having become almost a footnote during a time when the media was running from the O.J. Simpson trial to the Unabomber.  Wigland risks everything he has in order to come clean on the deadly practices of the industry he worked for, and the movie tells his story ably.But the movie also tells the story of Lowell Bergman, CBS Producer who fights to air Wigland's story. And it tells of CBS's cowardly attempt to snuff it out. Each of these entities could have its own story, but THE INSIDER tries to tell them all and loses its focus in the process. Is the movie centered around Wigland, who risked the most? Is it about Bergman's fight to protect his sources? Or is it a damning indictment of the big-business news industry?Michael Mann would have been better to pick one of these players and focus on it. The movie begins with Bergman in Iran, setting up an interview. That scene was an apparent attempt to show Bergman's skill as a producer, but other than showing some exotic middle eastern scenery, it added little to the film that could not have been explained with a few lines of dialogue. The result is an overly long movie that has Wigland's story taking a back seat to the story of Bergman's stature.The female characters are weak, as another reviewer had pointed out. Wigland's family disintegrates from the pressure he brought on his family, but you don't really see the love they have. Dianne Venora is wooden as Wigland's wife, a role made much worse by her pathetic, Scarlett O'Hara-ish southern accent. She never questions her husband's choosing to play with the kids while she's left to unpack the moving boxes. This is love?Russell Crowe does an admirable job playing a complicated character, but suffers a bit under Mann's depiction of him. There was so much more his character could've added to it all.What I wanted this movie to show me was why Wigland risked everything to do what he did. Instead, it simply displays the facts as it sees them and doesn't go far in answering the question "why?" Nevertheless, THE INSIDER does a decent job at telling a tough story.

reviews.review_title: Great acting but the movie was long!
reviews.content: This movie was truly a masterpiece when it comes to acting. Having said that let me also say that the movie was long and it's span was felt by the crowd.There were many scenes that could have been easily avoided and edited out of the final version. The movie is also extremely "quiet". There are many moments where people stare at each other for an average of one and a half minute without really "connecting" with the crowd.Again the acting by EVERYONE was superb. And Michael Mann's touch was evident throughout the movie. When the "Insider" was standing at the beach pondering the result of his actions it was pretty much a modern version of Sonny Crockett at the Miami beach before he had to arrest his girlfriend.I think that the movie-goers that are going for action will be disapointed. However those of you that are in for a good suspence film and would like to see how reality sometimes is better than fiction this film is truly one of the best out there.

I walked into an advanced screening of this film thinking it should be okay at best.  Mann's last film "Heat" had all of this hype surrounding the casting of Deniro and Pacino.  And a lot of people were left feeling let down by "Heat" (including myself),  but this film the "Insider" draws you in like some type of cinematic whirlpool.  I will not spoil the movie but merely state how this film affected me.Russell Crowe gives a great layered performance as the main character.  In the way he conveys the pressure he is being put through by the tobacco company, 60 minutes, his family and all sorts of other influences is almost painful but stunning to watch.  At times I wanted to yell at the screen and say "will you just leave the guy alone". Truly a man against the world feeling.  Pacino is very understated but powerful when the script calls for it.  I thought he was very well cast as the producer for 60 minutes.Another great aspect of this film is the way it lays bear the inside workings of the television and print media.  I thought stock brokers werebrutal.  Truly interesting to watch and to witness how a news story comes together.Well all in all a great story with well acted characters through out this film.  If you feel like being interested and educated by a film.  Well the "Insider" is most definitely for you.

reviews.review_title: Movie will work well in video
reviews.content: This film will work well on video since it has a lot of close-ups.This is a fine film with great performances featuring one of the heroes of our time, Jeffery Wigand. He is like Schindler in the sense of not being intrinsically heroic but circumstances bring him to do heroic things.

I went to see this movie in the theater and I really enjoyed it.Michael Mann is excellent at creating films that are long as well as entertaining.  I have not seen a movie that long that is that good since "English Patient".Al Pacino as Lowell Bergman was very good.  He has the right kind of acting qualities to play this role.Russel Crowe as Jeffery Wigland was not the greatest performance but I thought he did a good job.The supporting cast was good as well.  Christopher Plummer was good as Mike Wallace.  Debbie Mazar was good as Debbie DeLuca.  Diane Venora was good as Wigland's wife and Gina Gershon had a small role yet an excellent one as Helen Caperelli.This is definitely one to see in the theater!

It just sickens me to think that something like this could happen. There is no way we can have freedom in this country if big companies can push around the media.This movie was riveting, and it really drew me in. Watch out though, there is a lot of weird camera movement so I wouldn't sit too close to the screen.

reviews.review_title: Because Risking everything is worth it
reviews.content: The quality of a great movie is its ability to crawl under your skin and involve you in the plot.  When you are literally waiting for the next thing to happen, for the next scene to come along and the story to continue to develope.  Add two major stars, one established, the other up and coming, and an ensemble cast and chances are you will wind up a winner everytime.Al Pacino is the 60 Minutes Producer out for the story and Russell Crowe is the former research scientist out for nothing at all, but he holds a secret that Pacino pries out of him that will change the face of the tobacco industry as we know it.  In this day and age NOW of knowing the cancer risks, the addiction, all things bad about cigarettes, the secret we learn isn't the reason to see this movie.  Rather it is the acting performances put on by the cast and the expert direction of Michael Mann, the sometimes too stylish director of previous Pacino hit "Heat" and the formerly the director of "Miami Vice"  he finds his mark so brilliantly here in the movie, using all the right techniques at all the right times and gets the most out of his actors, from little known Debbie Mazar to seductress Gina Gershon as a believable corporate lawyer.  The question surrounding this movie is not if it will get nominated come Oscar time, the question is just how many statues will it win?  So far this is the only real competition American Beauty has come Oscar time.

In a nutshell, I thought this movie was terrific.  I have been waiting for it to come out, which is rare for me to await any release date.  Michael Mann, Al Pacino and Russell Crowe all deserve a great deal of credit for wonderful direction and superb acting.It was a thriller that relied on legal obligations, the corporate bottom line, a journalist's obstinance and another man's beliefs to drive its impact.  I will likely see this movie again.

Just came back from watching The Insider, and I must say that I thought it was absolutely excellent! The acting was incredible by both Pacino and Crowe, and the rest of the cast - I definitely recommend people see it. It has all the elements a great film should have! I give it two thumbs up! Brilliant film:-) Elle

The Insider shows a remarkable improvement on commercial american Movies both in its contents and from. this one is departing from the predictable patterns that most of the American film industry is tied to. the expression is also very creative, visually and also with a very unusual music highlighting technique. i wish american producers would do more of this, trying to shape the taste of the general public instead of shaping themselves around existing demands.

reviews.review_title: I'd love to see inside the head of the fool that crewed that DOP!
reviews.content: To be perfectly honest I have no idea why I was interested in this film or why, for that matter, it turned out to be worth every penny I payed to see it. The actual story itself is as true (and somewhat boring), HOWEVER with a little help from some brilliant dialogue writers, a great director and some big name actors the film excels.Posting a time close to three hours "The Insider" keeps you hooked until the credits and will leave you marveling at how far Russel Crowe has come from his early days as a small town bully in countless Australian feature films.Apart from minor plot difficulties (something which obviously couldn't be helped if the factual integrity was to be maintained) the only real criticism I have of "The Insider" was the camera work. The Steadicam wasn't steady, which was just plain annoying, and the DOP seemed to have a fetish for the technique of pulling focus - an effect that tires after the tenth time it is used. Oh yeah, in the restaurant scene the boom can be seen in one of the shots. Poor form.At the end of the day "The Insider" is a fantastic film that deserves all the accolades it may receive. However, if the photography is mentioned in any kind of positive way, my faith in the Academy Awards will be shot forever.:)

reviews.review_title: A perfectly directed emotional thriller with a great cast and incredible performances.
reviews.content: The Insider is one of the most incredible movies I have ever seen. The movie is totally devoid of sex, violence, gunshots, car chases, huge explosions, overblown special effects, cheap gags, false sincerity, clichés and cute animals. And yet it is utterly absorbing, gripping and powerful, a story of how two (fairly) ordinary guys face an overwhelming situation. The chemistry between Al Pachino and Russell Crowe is electrifying. Micheal Mann has directed the best movie of his career with superb camera work, soundtrack and compelling performances. Don't believe what you hear - it isn't too long, in fact it wasn't long enough. It had my total concentration from start to finish and it left me emotionally drained.Summary: A perfectly directed emotional thriller with a great cast and incredible performances.

reviews.review_title: It tells you the truth! Impressive performance by Al Pacino
reviews.content: It's extremely realistic in its history, and reflects the society we're living in and the media world. Al Pacino is fantastic, his role is simply heroic. Still, the movie is a bit too long and some details in the characters are not convincing: can you believe a top manager of a tobacco multinational still has to finish paying his car and is so worried about losing his job??? Come on...

Michael Mann's `The Insider' is not a great film.  It is a masterpiece.  It is simply one of the great films made in the past decade.  The criticism in which `The Insider' received was that it was not an original film.  It also been unfairly scrutinized by the media for it's `inaccurate' portrayal of the facts.  People often forget that the `The Insider' is not a recreation of a factual documentation of a story, but it is simply a film, it is the highest art of it's kind.What makes `The Insider' a masterpiece?  To answer this question, film lovers who would disagree with me, should watch the films of Howard Hawks. In both of the directors' films, they share an uncanny common parallel. They are masters of the physical aspect of the film making process.  Both directors believe that films must tell a story through the structural narrative drive, transitions of the images, cinematography, fluctuations in filmic rhythm, and especially the subtle execution of the realization of the film's thematic concerns.  All of these qualities are masterfully demonstrated in `The Insider.'In `The Insider' the film's ability to drive it's narrative, which it immeasurably serves to examine the character's psychological insight, makes it one of the great cinematic accomplishments in recent times.  This is the aspect of the film that causes people to denounce the film as `unoriginal.' Yet, `The Insider' serves it purpose by presenting it's narrative with a force that can't be produced in a thousand of these so-called `original' films made today.  `The Insider' is presented with candor and doesn't use any gimmicks to tell its story.`The Insider' is also one of the few films, in the tradition of Howard Hawks, as a film, which uses the aesthetic of oversight, of creating the mise en scene of implication rather than overly stating the film's thematic concerns.  Underneath the surfaces lie complex tensions between the character's pretense and their conscious feelings.  `The Insider' could have gone to great lengths of how smoking kills millions of people each year by showing an autopsy of a diseased lung or a demonstration of injecting nicotine on laboratory rats, but "The Insdier" is not a Spielberg film, it is a Michael Mann film.The photography of the film can also be described as momentous.  Dante Spinotti, arguably the best cinematographer today, executed the photography where it serves the film's purpose by fusing the image with tension and apprehension.  The most effective shot in `The Insider' is probably the close-up with the telephoto lens.  This shot effectively distorts the background, which gives the image an unclear tension, which infuses the moment.  The dull blue-green hues of the film also serve it purpose of creating an insomniac effect where the two characters are stuck in a nightmare in which they can't wake up from.With this film, along with `Heat,' proclaims Director Michael Mann as the best storyteller today.  Finally, the successor to Howard Hawks has been found.

The Insider is one of the few movies that I can watch over and over again without becoming bored.  Every time I watch it, I notice something new--I come away from it with more of an understanding of the brilliance of this film.  Make no mistake, this is drama at its very best, with three outstanding actors--Al Pacino as 60 Minutes producer Lowell Bergman, Russell Crowe as ex-tobacco scientist Dr. Jeffrey Wigand, and Christopher Plummer as 60 Minutes' very own Mike Wallace--surrounded by an effective supporting cast.I won't bore you with a synopsis of the plot.  Too many reviewers get bogged down on plot and focus too little on what does or does not make a film work.In the case of The Insider, everything works, with the possible exception of a bad southern accent from Diane Venora, who has some great performances under her belt (The Jackal).  Let's start with the music.  A lot of people said it was bizarre but worked.  This couldn't be more true.  One of the scores used sounds much like a chant, but it works bacause it accentuates the conflict that is Dr. Wigand's life.  Among this film's most effective scenes is the one when Dr. Wigand is about to deliver a deposition and he standing before a body fo water trying to decide whether to go ahead and do it or pull out for fear of being arrested when he returns to Kentucky. You have to see it to truly comprehend the brilliance of the music of The Insider.Not enough could be said about the performances by Russell Crowe, Al Pacino, and Christopher Plummer.  These three actors are as fine as it gets. Pacino had fallen into a slump where he was over-acting a bit, as evidenced by his mediocre performance in Scent of a Woman, but he came back stronger than ever in The Insider, which was his strongest performance since The Godfather Part II.  Lowell Bergman is a rebel among conformists in The Insider and Pacino captures the conflict Bergman endured during the Wigand debacle--when 60 Minutes really dropped the ball.Plummer was brilliant as Mike Wallace.  In addition to actually looking like Wallace, Plummer acted like him too.  It was almost as if Wallace was playing himself in The Insider.Russell Crowe made a statement in The Insider.  Coming off an incredible performance in LA Confidential, Crowe, with his remarkable ability to play any role, proved to the world that The Insider was just the begining of a remarkable career.  Crowe is now in the same category as Sean Connery, Harrison Ford, Gene Hackman, Tom Hanks, etc.  He is here to stay and he is a giant.The Insider is simply one of the top 5 best movies of the '90s, maybe of all-time.  It's a classic and I recommend to anyone to see it because they won't regret it.

reviews.review_title: Riviting movie, left you on the edge of your seat.
reviews.content: The Insider is the story of Jeffery Wigand (again Oscar-worthy Russell Crowe), a former tobacco company scientist that begins to rebel against his former employer.  With the help of 60 Minutes producer played by Al Pacino. Wigand tells the story of what the tobacco companies do not want you to know.  He then realizes that maybe everything he is doing isn't worth all he has lost, (i.e. his family, his safety, his job).  This film was a real controversial masterpiece of modern times.  It was nominated for 7 Academy Awards, and though I agree with giving Best Picture, Actor, and Director to American Beauty, this film should have won something, possably Best Screenplay.

reviews.review_title: An inside look at 2 moguls, 60 Minutes and the Tobacco Industry
reviews.content: When you put two people like Al Pacino and Russell Crowe, you know you have a good thing.This movie, although a bit on the lengthy side at 2 and a half hours, keeps you pretty much involved the entire way.  Al Pacino plays great journalist looking for the big story, but gets personal when Russell Crowe loses his job as a researcher for a big tobacco firm, and starts to come loose at the edges because of some damaging information he is aware of.The movie provides some very original plot twists, and kept it surprisingly real.  They probably could have cut about 30 mins of footage, but after seeing Mike Wallace freak out...I can understand the length.  I definately recommend, but get comfy.

reviews.review_title: Do the big guys always win? Is the fight worth it?
reviews.content: Michael Mann exceeds himself. He leaves behind the fast pace of Heat and shows a careful attention to detail. This film is all about reading between the lines. From beginning to end we are watching what people are not saying instead of what they are saying.The story briefly;  Sampson and Goliath but, without the frilly morality many American films cling to so slavishly. Dr Jeffrey Wigand (Crowe) is a research scientist for a large Tobacco company. He threatens the company policy of always keep the public in the dark and he is sacked for knowing too much.  Wigand struggles with his conscience. Does he keep his severance package (which includes a Healthcare plan for his family. His eldest daughter, ironically is asthmatic!)and become a company stooge? Or does he stand up, in isolation to warn the country of what is kept from them?This struggle is finally decided when he is pushed too far by anonymous threats against him and his family.  He turns whistle blower, with the help of Lowell Bergman (Pacino), 60second producer who cleverly lures Wigand into the bag whilst retaining his journalistic integrity.The crescendo of twists and turns leads us through Wigand`s angst and Bergman`s questioning of ethics.  The ending is not what you may expect. There`s no parties or champagne. Instead our two leading characters come out both winners and losers.Look out for the scene where Wigand is alone in his hotel room and Bergman tries to contact him via the hotel manager and a "cell phone". This scene is engaging and the diversity in the music used is beautiful. It captures a few seconds of true humanity.The fact that this is based on true events adds so much punch to the film it`s easy to forget we`re being entertained. It also gives us an insight into how the whistleblowers of our age are subject to massive smear campaigns. How would our lives stand up to the scrutiny of a media microscope?If you`re expecting the kind of pace in Heat you`ll get it after the introductions. If your`e expecting a Mann action extravaganza go rent  The Die Hard Trilogy or something. If you want a thinking man`s action flick rent LA Heat and Heat. If however you think you can handle the truth try this one. Be warned it may challenge your grey matter, unlike the formaluaic, good will out American Pie concept you may have.

reviews.review_title: great premise but a little to drawn out and too much cutting
reviews.content: This movie was very good for about the first hour and a half, crowe plays a great science nerd and pachino is solid. The wife of russel crowes character and the bald person in the misisippi portion of the movie (much better than his weak work in Paycheck) also had strong performances. It seems as though after the dramatic non-happening in the first part of the movie it just seems to drag on, like producer and directors were saying to themselves "we need more al pachino" and some of the stuff the movie modified at the end seemed like total baloney to say the least, it seemed like the movie lacked a legal consultant... great middle and begining but the ending is too drawn out in my opinion. I would give more detail but I would spoil the plot for those who haven't seen the movie yet.

reviews.review_title: The film is a modern Fable, a great work in the tragic tradition.
reviews.content: The story of a Doctor who is fired for doing the right thing. The film shows how corporate dictators can ruin the life of a decent man.  It is a tragic tale, with the power to open the eyes of all who seek the truth. This film will be more appreciated with the passage of time.  It is better than Citizen Kane, the protagonist reveals what is best in the human spirit.

reviews.review_title: Television Journalism: Is it Money, People or Just News?
reviews.content: "The Insider" combines the very basics of television journalism with a vision on how shows like "60 Minutes" affect the lives of people who are interviewed with those who get the story. "60 Minutes" is a very well respected news series and one I have watched for many years but it's nice to be reminded that some of the players -- both the people who produce the show and the people they interview -- can give up their souls in the process of telling the rest of us how it really is.The acting, in particular that of Al Pacino's and Russel Crowe's, was simply incredible.  Michael Mann's signature combination of strong visuals and subtle sounds gave the movie the gritty feeling he does so well and also so enthralled me for most of the almost three hours.  Mann's hand in the movie added several more layers to the experience making it one I thoroughly enjoyed.  This movie was crafted very, very well; it makes you think.This movie deserves to win some awards somewhere.

I saw this film on television on April 11, 2003. Right after the US-invasion in Bagdad. Right after the US-ambassador in Brussels told the press that he didn't like how Belgian media commented on the US-operation in Iraq. The Insider is about pressure on the press by big international concerns (in this case the tobacco industry). Since the Bush-administration in the USA took over, the interests of industry and government overlap. How free can the press be when this happens? Not all journalists are as brave as Lowell Bergman. Some Americans should read about the evil propaganda methods of Goebels (remember?). And Michael Mann has still a lot of shooting to do to make clear that the freedom of the press is essential in democracy, as important as opposition in Congress, as important as the voice and the clearvoyance of Mr Michael Mann himself. R-E-S-P-E-C-T T-H-I-S M-A-N.

The movie is filled with great actors to be sure.  But even the best acting can not save an otherwise dull story.  The movie is dull for two reasons. Everyone is now aware that smoking is not healthy, so that aspect of the movie now seems uneventful.  The movie is constrained from having flashing action scenes, because real life is not that way and this story is suppose to be remotely close to life of a real insider.  The most troubling part of the film is its length.  It needs to be cut by at lease 45 minutes to be more bearable.

Michael Mann has done it again.  He consistently creates taut projects that appeal to heart and mind of his audience.  I wonder if and when he will ever receive credit for the work he has done.  I would certainly rank him in the top 10 directors of the last 30 years.  Go see "The Insider".  You'll enjoy it whether you smoke or not.

Forget the poetic liberties taken with the actual events (e.g., Dr. Wigand's daughter has spina bifida, not asthma), the petty putdowns and complaints about casting choices, makeup, pace of the movie, etc., and side plots such as section on the Unabomber stakeout towards the end. This film is a riveting tale of corruption in corporate America, of valuing money and personal advantage above traditional, basic fundamental human values such as respecting human life and telling the truth. Two courageous but imperfect men, and their allies, prevail in the face of an army of greedy, dishonest, egoistic, cynical people surrounding them. As such, this film does a masterful job in telling this story, in a powerful fashion that no documentary (well, perhaps if Ken Burns produced it, and Stephen Ambrose was still around to be interviewed, not having succumbed to smoking induced lung cancer) could have conveyed. It's a heroic, well-crafted morality tale, and well deserves its comparison to "All the President's Men." In fact, I think cinematically it is much better.

After Heat, I was a little worried that Mann wouldn't be able to present the same level of character, intensity and drama on what would seem to be a "boring" subject matter. How wrong was I.Russell Crowe and Al Pacino both give outstanding performances. Crowe is one of the most talented "new" actors around. See L.A. Confidential for proof.Mann's use of intense lighting, close-ups and wide landscape shots to establish atmosphere are more refined than in Heat. While most directors either ignore the environment and how it relates to the story or characters, or use it as eye candy, Mann understands the importance of atmosphere. Music, photography, lighting, all can say more in a single scene than most directors can get across in a whole movie.I have to respectfully disagree with Gooch-4 about the lack of focus of the film. The story is about ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances. Wigand is the ordinary person thrust into the center of the maelstrom. We need to see Bergman's fight and the corporate happenings to understand the full extent of Wigand's struggle. As to the "why," it seems fairly obvious that Wigand simply set out to do the right thing.

I honestly would have given this only a 9 due to a teeny few overblown scenes, but I am so galled that the movie isn't ranked higher that I gave it a 10.  =)Make no mistake, this is a mental thriller.  Nobody gets sliced, diced, there is no nudity, and remarkably little swearing.  I guess considering modern society's taste for instant gratification and our increasingly short attention span, I should be surprised it didn't score even lower.But this is a thinking person's movie, and a damn good one at that.  Don't expect big explosions and sudden slaughters... you won't get it.  Even without knowing that this was all based on a true story, I enjoyed every minute of the movie... and I think anyone who watches it with an open, unhurried mind (sprinkled with a dose of imagination) can't help but be enthralled.One comment on how poorly the movie did during the *laughs* Oscars and the *groans* Box Office:  as time goes on, both these institutions become more and more bland, with the oh-so-corporatized aim of pleasing the great masses by sticking to the least common denominator.  But maybe the movie wasn't a commercial success just because The Insider is just too left-of-center. Maybe some really subtle pressure from some really large powers-that-be urged that it really shouldn't do so well...  hmmm, what do you think?

I'm a film junkie, and that means that not only have I seen every film that is out right now, but I have been choosy in recommending films to my friends. This movie, THE INSIDER, has been infused with so much care in its direction, it is a much rarer commodity than many would think. Yes, it was long. Yes, Michael Mann likes long.But what does that matter, for a film that can put one in touch in the most basic levels with a character that you don't really know much about for those 2 and some odd hours?Coupled with an unusually  good performance (for production company movies) put forth by Russell Crowe as Jeffrey Wygand, this film, with its dramatization, worts and all, brings forth more truth about America than any film on the block in the past few years.

reviews.review_title: Should have waited till more in the mood for a slower-paced movie
reviews.content: Great movie, but I should have seen it when I was in a more contemplative state of mind.  Russell Crowe's performance is fascinating--Al Pacino always grabs my attention--and I found myself quite curious about what has happened to Jeffrey Wigand since the events depicted in the film.

Michael Mann was a skillful director. This is a great true life story. It's well acted and directed, well edited, good music. It has a 96% score on RT. Will it be an all time classic? No, just for the simple reason that this is a movie made by boys, with boys and for boys. It is pretty much a kind of male fantasy. Apart from the true story of how American tobacco was exposed, the main concern of the movie is male friendship. The film miserably fails the Bechdel test - there is not a single scene in the movie with two women having any kind of conversation. Well there are a couple of very brief scenes with Russell Crowe's wife and daughters talking to each other, but guess what, they're literally muted - you can't hear what they're saying. There are actually only a few minutes in a nearly 3 hour long film where you even have women at all on screen and talking. Crowe's wife is portrayed as a whining ungrateful housewife.  There's an attractive young woman working at CBS, who appears to be nothing more than Pacino's flunky. She has no character to speak of, and all she does is follow Pacino's barked instructions, even when he phones her up in the middle of the night. But I suppose she does provide a bit of eye candy here and there (she is wearing full make up and deshabille when Pacino's call wakes her in the middle of the night). Pacino's wife, again a very tiny part, is the only sympathetic female in the movie, and all she does is basically look adoringly at him and support him when things are going wrong.  She does seem to have a job, though it's not revealed what she does. I am sure there were women involved in all sorts of ways in the original true story, and there could have been all sorts of ways of bringing them into the story, but Mann (appropriate name, btw), chooses not to. As, I say, it's a boys' story. I am looking back on this from 23 years on, and some might say, oh, that's just how things were in Hollywood back then, and there is a smidgeon of truth in that, but really not that much. A quick google shows 1999 movies like The Virgin Suicides, Girl Interrupted, Boys Don't Cry, Election. Even in 1999 Mann was a bit of a dinosaur. I also just rewatched Heat, which is also regarded as a great classic, and I really don't know why. It's just the same: blokes, blokes and more blokes, shouting at each other, bromancing, fighting and punching, making phone calls, giving long brooding looks.

I think this movie captures the stress and emotions involved in a situation like the one our main caracters finds themselves in, in a perfectly credible way. The film builds tension in a magnificent way, and every scene Al Pacino and Russell Crowe are in together turns into pure magic.
Smart, well acted film and a nice respite from screaming Pacino. Crowe is excellent as is the entire supporting cast.

A tremendous performance by Crowe and Pacino and superb direction by Michael Mann keeps this movie engaging right till the end. Who would've thought a drama dealing with Tobacco companies would be this entertaining?

So here we are again with the beautiful & slow structure of Michael Mann. Here though, the build that is created throughout one man's mind. Christopher Plummer's take on Mike Wallace is so intense and real. But then again, I am a product of 60 Minutes. Unlike Mann, here we are treated to dialogue driven scenes and even a visual moment as fatherhood takes it toll
Strong performances. Mike Wallace character crushed it
Excellent performance of the actors. Based on the true story, still relevant today. I knew this was box office flop... maybe lengthy, but it's a good film.

Based on a true story, this film about a tobacco company executive-turned-whistleblower is an exciting behind-the-scenes movie about television journalism and corporate crime. Also, Al Pacino gave a great bunch of speeches throughout this film.
Excellent corporate thriller, probably just as good as Kill the Messenger (2014) and Dark Waters. Same kind of movie

Russell Crowe plays a former executive at a big tobacco company who's talked into whistleblowing by a producer of 60 Minutes played by Al Pacino.  
Michael Mann directs this film based on true events.  As with most films by Mann it's about thirty minutes longer than it needs to be.  That being said I love any movie where Pacino yells out a monologue….which coincidentally is every movie he's in.
Great performances, tense drama

It's an interesting story but it's just so long and slow. I lost patience about halfway and just read about the plot. It's definitely the kind of thing I would take 10 minutes to read a well-written article about, rather than 2.5 hours to watch a slow movie about.

This is one of those films that really means something, and so important that it stands its ground and the test of time, even more than 20 years after its release. Very few films fit that discription. The true story and the article that The Insider is based on is so fundamental that it has lead to a radical worldwide change in how a certain product is produced, or at least distributed, and even the film alone made its contribution in this matter. In addition the plot is a dive into the ruthlessness of big business and media corporations, where the situation has become even worse since then. This makes it not just a film drama, but also a historical document. Regardless of this, when the performances from top and well known actors are at such a level that you forget that its not reality you're watching, but actualy just a fictiionalized version of it, that's when film making is where it ideally should be. Then it becomes magic, and director Michael Mann and his crew must certainly have felt this during the rehersals and shootings. Main role holder Russell Crowe probably does his best ever performance, so credible that we forget that he is acting. He truly becomes the character, something that always is prior for making the best films. Even Al Pacino, who usually delivers some ultimate version of himself, steps out and into this bubble, and the interaction between him and Crowe is outstanding. It's all so convincing that the late Christopher Plummer just might fool you to believe that it really is Mike Wallace playing himself. On top of that Bruce McGill has a verbal anger outburst so convincing that the actors receiving it literally get scared. Also Mike Moore becomes a good actor by playing himself. All in all there is nothing negative to say about this film, and it gets even better the second time around.
Masterful direction and performances, especially by Crowe and psycho Al Pacino as he becomes in this film
As close as you can get to the perfect smart blockbuster, a genre seldom seen nowadays.

Based on the way they set up the plot of The Insider, I was expecting more of a man-on-the-run type of story. They certainly make it seem like there’s some significant danger for the main characters. I think the primary reason that I found the film a bit underwhelming was simply because it didn’t feel like the stakes were as high as the movie was implying. Yes, the men involved faced severe opposition and standing up to the tobacco industry caused them great personal frustration. But it never seemed their lives were in danger. Likewise, the content of their “groundbreaking” story is such old news to me, and I struggle to understand why it mattered so much. Was it really that shocking to people in 1996 that cigarette corporations knew their products were life-threatening and that they actively worked to make them more addictive? I was in my late teens at that time, and I’m pretty sure that I assumed all of this was true. Despite all of my issues, when I was able to go with the flow and accept the story of The Insider as a high stakes endeavor, I found some enjoyment from it. The tone and atmosphere is excellent and offers plenty of nervous tension throughout. I appreciated the performance of Al Pacino, because he isn’t over-the-top and crazy like he has become in many modern movies. I do wish they had cast someone more charismatic and interesting than Russell Crowe to play the lead role. However after watching the actual interview, it doesn’t seem like Wigand is all that exciting, so perhaps Crowe was delivering the performance just right. Which brings me to my other important positive about The Insider. It was not a perfect movie by any stretch of the imagination, but it did interest me enough that I made a point of seeking out the original video of WIgand’s 60 Minutes interview. I suppose, for a movie based on a true story, that’s a big win. The Insider might have lacked something for me, but at least I was intrigued.

Michael Mann's The Insider is about Jeffrey Wigand's (Russell Crowe) battle against the tobacco industry.  More specifically, the film is about corporate greed and the sacrifices that individuals are willing to make for the greater cause.  While the movie undoubtedly has an important message and story to share, it is hindered by its length, clocking in at twenty minutes shy of three hours. It could have been trimmed significantly (the first fifteen minutes or so add nothing to the story, for example) without decreasing the impact.  There are also several odd directorial decisions by Mann.  In one scene, litigators approach the courthouse, but a quarter of the screen is obscured by an out of focus newspaper box.  Despite these criticisms, the film is worth watching for its message and for powerful performances from top to bottom.

Michael Mann's political legal drama The Insider (1999) is a testament to Mann's skillful prowess as an American auteur. Mann directs The Insider with an inspiring sense of justice and sensitivity towards his subject Jeffrey Wigand. Mann's riveting direction keeps you stunned, shocked, nervous, and furious at how big tobacco companies operate and intimate witnesses testifying against their unethical behaviors that kill people. The Insider will surely be remembered alongside other phenomenal classics of the investigative, legal drama and paranoia thriller genres like All the President's Men, Zodiac, Spotlight, or Dark Waters. 

Russell Crowe is sympathetic and powerful playing a middle aged man in his youth with neat grey hair dye. Crowe conveys his paranoia, frustration, rage, warmth, intelligence, and fear with equal sincerity and kindness towards the patriotic hero and tobacco whistleblower Jeffrey Wigand. Crowe is at the top of his game in a peak performance from this acting legend.

Al Pacino is outstanding as Lowell Bergman, a fierce CBS producer for 60 minutes, who bravely stands behind Wigand and against CBS' cowardly tactics to bury an imperative story for the safety of Americans everywhere. Pacino's persistent rage and righteous indignation admirably defends the virtues of the media as the protectors of American society in their role as the fourth estate. On the other hand, Christopher Plummer adeptly portrays Mike Wallace in his straightforward journalism and cowardice in not defending Wigand when he needed him. The Insider makes Wallace look terribly selfish and only concerned with his career legacy, now tarnished by his own miserable choices.

Diane Venora is hurtful as Liane Wigand, who cannot bring herself to stop acting like an entitled rich housewife long enough to support her husband during his time of need. Venora perfectly captures her selfish decisions. Opposite, we have Lindsay Crouse as Pacino's steadfast and supportive wife, desperately trying to contend with his stubborn ways and searing situation. I liked Debi Mazar as Debbie De Luca the researcher for Pacino. I wish she was in The Insider more as she's hauntingly beautiful and commands your attention any time she speaks or glances over.

Bruce McGill is poignant as Ron Motley in a sturdy role of robust accusatory speeches. On the other side of journalism, Philip Baker Hall depicts CBS' boss Don Hewitt as a cowardly traitor taking money from big tobacco in unethical conduct. Stephen Tobolowsky, Gina Gershon, Michael Gambon, Rip Torn, and Cliff Curtis all have memorable cameos that leave a mark in your brain. 

Eric Roth and Michael Mann's script is poignant, well researched, mature, and informative with a deep empathy for the victims of big tobacco's endless campaign to stop whistleblowers. Dante Spinotti's cinematography is gorgeous and breathtaking, whether shooting a blue ocean or black night in a parking lot. You are held in silent suspense by his isolating shot framing. Lisa Gerrard and Pieter Bourke's score is chilling with ambient noises, holy choirs, and soft acoustic melodies. Bill Myer's realistic make-up goes a long way for The Insider's verisimilitude. 

In all, The Insider will stay in my mind forever as an important film and special classic drama from Michael Mann.

This may very well be the most effective and well-made 'exposé/whistleblower' film ever made, period. The story focuses less on documenting a grand conspiracy to suppress a larger truth from an omniscient perspective, but instead allows its story to be told through the eyes of 'boots-on-the-ground' characters, allowing the twists of the narrative to impact the viewer more personally. Having coincidentally also recently seen Mann's Public Enemies, on which he shares a similar combination role of director, producer, and writer, there is a unique element to his filmmaking that deserves mention: his willingness to introduce characters, provide development to them, and give them an impactful role in the story, and then to allow them to fall away without any grand resolution to their particular arc, which I feel is more representative of reality than giving every John and Jane some sort of bow-on-top independent story. He's not afraid to recruit quality talent for these roles, either. For an example of this type of character, look no further than Bruce McGill, who delivers one of the most dramatically constructed speeches of the film, but probably sees less than 30 or 40 minutes of screentime elapse between his first and last appearance. Gambon arguably serves as the most prominent antagonist in the film, but is shown sparingly and his ultimate fate is never commented on. Great performance from Crowe, but I'm less confident that Pacino really embraces his characters as much as he just alters the volume of his voice once in a while. Given that the era of corporate deception, whistleblowers, and gag orders has persisted without flagging to the present day, The Insider still feels fresh and relevant. (4.5/5)

Possibly the most famous modern film to explore journalistic ethics is All the President's Men (1976) a stolid attempt at a thriller that never quite convinces it's audiences of it's convictions. I personally did not like the film and when I chose to watch this film, aware that it had many similarities to that film, I hoped to see Michael Mann put his own unique spin on ground covered in many other Hollywood films. Fortunately I was not disappointed as while the film is slow, contemplative and deathly serious it gives you a sense of the impact that whistleblowing can have on both journalists and the whistleblowers themselves much better than the more staid Alan J. Pakula did. This may be Mann's best film as he wrestles with serious themes while making a seriously entertaining and consistently tense film.

Scientist Jeffrey Wigand, Russell Crowe, was employed as an executive at Big Tobacco corporation Brown & Williamson and is now willing to reveal information that would force the CEOs of the major tobacco companies to admit that they know the negative effect that cigarettes have on people. Lowell Bergman, Al Pacino, who serves as the producer of 60 Minutes attempts to coax this information out of him as Wigand's difficult personality and the breakup of his marriage complicate their interactions. A further issue is the fact that Wigand had signed a confidentiality agreement which would legally prevent him from revealing the information to the public. A segment with popular news presenter Mike Wallace, Christopher Plummer, is taped but CBS refuses to run the segment under the guise of concern about the legal repercussions they could face but most likely because they want to be bought by Westinghouse, who own Brown & Williamson, in a corporate merger. In the aftermath of this event Wigand spirals out of control while Bergman desperately tries to contact him and have the information released to the public.

The film pulls the risky move of having it's perspective shift midway through the film as it turns from being a Wigand-centric film to a movie primarily concerned with journalistic ethics and Bergman's fight to have them upheld. This is where the film becomes most interesting as while the first half engages you with it's tale of Bergman slowly extracting information from an emotionally fraught Wigand the threats do not really come into play until the second act. It is there that we get a wonderful sequence that is able to plunge into the depths of despair and loss as Wigand's sacrifices have seemingly amounted to nothing while he stands alone. These are the sort of scenes we never got in similarly themed journalism movies as there is plenty of ranting and raving about the fear of losing money and the stresses it places on family members but the impact of this loss is rarely captured so closely. Mann intelligently throws all the facts that we need to know at us in the first half and then leaves us with the characters that have been slowly built up with their tensions boiling over and conflicts coming to play.

Mann also has the benefit of working with a stellar cast as Crowe and Pacino are reliably magnetic but Diane Venora and Plummer steal scenes in the background and add depth to characters that need to be more than plain caricature. Pacino, who I believe to be the true lead of the film, could be accused of going too far but it is fun to watch him chew scenery and here he works with a part that asks him to hold real convictions and provides him with lines worthy of an actor of his stature. Crowe is well cast as a tortured, obsessive man as he plays socially inept and volatile much better than he would in A Beautiful Mind (2001). Here he feels like a man who has lived a regular life for a long time with his personality defects only really causing problems every now and then but creating a sudden implosion for him now. One has to wonder how Plummer, a highly respected actor who would eventually get his due, was not nominated for Best Supporting Actor with competition as weak as Jude Law in The Talented Mr. Ripley (1999).

This isn't necessarily a film that will have fans of Miami Vice excited but for those who enjoy thrillers and films with something to say about the state of news media this will be a wholly satisfying experience.

As a film maker and huge mega fan of the industry, I am gobsmacked at what I just witnessed. The fact that it took me this long to even hear about, let alone witness a film of this calibre is baffling. I've loved pretty much everything Michael Mann has ever achieved with his directorial career, but here, he just creates this piece of entertainment that is raw and calculated and all sorts of grandiose that, I can confidently say, I've never ever seen anything quite like The Insider. Instead of his usual crime or thriller genre pick, Mann here decides to go for a true life story and biopic of fresh and epic proportions. Lowell Berman, is a CBS producer, on one of Americas biggest news shows, 60 Minutes. After returning from Tehran on a recent story, he stumbles across an obscure story of a man name Jeff Wigand, a former scientist and consultant for a massive tobacco company, who recently has just been fired, on false terms and he has some very big news. However when the tobacco company find out that their reputation and lively hoods are on the line, with Wigands secrets, not only can CBS not get enough of his story, but his life becomes threatened and family life destroyed, as the whistle blower, tries to do whats right. This film is a masterpiece, on so many levels. The cast, what a cast, Al Pacino, Russell Crowe, Rip Torn, Christopher Plummer and Michael Gambon make up just a portion of raw talent in this film and every single one of them are completely on top form, all off them, not a bad apple in the bunch. Every actor in the film lives their character and being a strong minded director about character and visualisation, Mann orchestrates this ensemble wonderfully, with time and consideration. Pacino is on fire as CBS producer Lowell, his drive, his motivation to get the truth out there is overwhelming, he delivers such a sense of emotion and passion, I actually think, this could be one of Pacino's finest moments. Crowe is just outstanding as Wigand, the man with everything to lose, his multi layered character is a sight to behold, as his family life is turned upside down and his past trudged through the mood. Equally Michael Gambon as the head of the large tobacco company, regardless of his limited screen time, is just out of this universe, he emits so much threat, so much evil and snide intentions, that his entire scene is edge of your seat, jaw dropping. And Christopher Plumber, oh my god, he just steals the screen, every single moment he is on it, literally chews it up and spits it out. He revels in every moment and his chemistry with Pacino is awe inspiring. The script is so well written, its engaging, thematic, arcing, tension filled,dialogue is real and passionate. There isnt a single flaw in any of it, its all required, it gives just the right amount of exposition, when it needs to and never more, leaving the story building and building, till our hearts cant take it any more. The actors deliver their characters and dialogue flawlessly and extra gratitude to Mann for clearly allowing these guys to go the full mile, it pays off in  every respect. The visual element, although not quite as flashy as his other work, is expertly crafted, with a wide range of colour palette and lighting. The way in which the sequences are crafted and edited together are kinetic and hypnotising, every single conversation, and there are a lot of them, just brings something new and stylistic to the table. The look and feel consistantly follow the themes and tones of whats going on, extreme close ups are used to wonderful effect, making us feel claustrophobic at times, putting us right where we want to be in the film. I havent seen this kind of cinematography ever and its wonderful, seemless and downright admirable. The use of music and choice of music is spot on, the soundtrack and score just resonate with your emotions, they pull even more out of the content, giving you a real sense of threat and helplessness as this entire debacle explodes over everyones face. Its polished, well directed, acted, producer, edited, filmed, the story is so rich with content and an utter joy to watch unravel. I literally fell deeper and deeper into every second of this film, torn apart by what was happening and transfixed on the screen, all the time. How often do you get that in a film? Not often enough, and missing this film, if you have any remote interest in the art form is a collosal mistake. It has such much texture, so much style and finesse, that it has now became one of my all time favorite films. I have nothing bad to say, its not over bloated, despite glancing over its run time, it doesnt bore, it never takes its foot of the pedal and it hits every mark it sets out to. I cant think of one thing at all to critize, and at is an achievement. If you havent seen this film, get on it right now.

This film is the definition of intense filmmaking. It's a thriller without set pieces, chases, shootouts, fist fights. It's a thriller that relies on silence, paranoia and tension above anything else to create thrills.

What makes this such a special thriller, to me, is the fact that Mann has shown multiple times that he can work in violent cinema to thrill, the most prominent being the legendary shootout in Heat. But this film shows that he doesn't have to.

The epic rise of Russell Crowe in his winning streak of Oscar nominated films begins in this expertly crafted and intelligently directed thriller. Michael Mann directs an excellent, very urgent and powerful thriller that has a lot on its mind and is filled with excellent performances from a very expansive and brilliant cast. The way everything develops in this paranoid thriller is excellent and it all moves at a fiery pace, the script is excellent at being intelligent whilst also developing its characters very well, which is the one element most films of this type seem to forget. It's scary to see how far a business will go to protect its secrets, which is why it is probably easier to just keep them hired.

The acting in this film is outstanding with everyone giving it their all. I'm a little surprised by the amount of awards Crowe was nominated for, not because he was bad, on the contrary, he gave a very realistic performance, but it's just that he was in the film for what felt like considerably less time than Al Pacino. Then again, it's hardly like he was in a supporting role, so it makes sense. Al Pacino gave a very passionate performance and felt like he was very involved with what was going on, as did veteran Christopher Plummer and wow, speaking of Plummer, he is amazing, give that guy a great script and he does absolute wonders with it, he was very exciting to watch, even if Pacino and Plummer didn't have accents but maybe they weren't supposed to, I'm not sure, another veteran actor Phillip Baker Hall does a good job as well. The only real problem I had with the acting was Michael Gambon, while he is an excellent character actor and still did a good job here, I can't ignore his dreadful accent in this film, if it's what's the real person is reported to have sounded like, then fine, but any time he spoke it just sounded like he was drunk.

The script is, like I said, excellent and develops the story in a very realistic way but I really loved how they developed the characters. Crowe's character, Jeffery Wigand, is given so many little nuances and little remarks when he talks to his daughters or students that it just makes it so real and really, really likeable. I really felt for his character and he was immediately sympathetic, thanks in part, again, to an excellent performance from Russell Crowe. Looking at the poster, I thought Pacino would be going against Crowe and would be trying to stop him and I am very surprised with what happened; it's refreshing to see something so different- showcasing people fighting for the truth. I also thought that in the interview they would hide his face behind a bug sheet of cardboard like I have seen in other films. As is the norm for a Michael Mann film, the technicals are all amazing, the film looked and sounded excellent; the soundtrack is very varied and excellent to listen to and the film looks absolutely amazing. I could watch Russell Crowe play in the driving range all night because of how beautiful that scene looked and if Michael Mann is the director, there is no question about it and it's certainly one of the best films he has directed, it's a very different style of film for him as well. This film was also made very quickly after the real event and I bet Michael Mann was pleased when he got the rights to make this, the TV version of the film is longer than the theatrical one, too, not all that sure why though. 'The Insider', or the more fitting originally titled, 'Man Of The People', the other title is still great as well, is smart, intense, thoughtful, political and all without firing a gun, now that's the way to do a thriller.

Big Tobacco and Big Business are the targets of this compelling drama based on an article in Vanity Fair, "The Man Who Knew Too Much," by Marie Brenner. Russell Crowe is Jeffrey Wigand; the whistleblower for a major tobacco company, who appears on the CBS investigative news program "60 Minutes," to detail how chemicals are used in the product to enhance a nicotine addiction. Corporate pressure, as the result of possible litigation, forces the segment to air in modified form. Al Pacino is the news producer Lowell Bergman, who repeatedly informs his sources that they have his word that he will protect them. Michael Mann directed and co-wrote the script with Eric Roth. This is among the most intelligent depictions of journalism since "All the President's Men." In the first hour, the story revolves around Crowe's hesitation about whether or not to do the interview, but in the second hour it shifts to focus on how financial implications can affect journalistic integrity. Bergman is credited as a consultant on the movie, so it is slanted to give him a favorable portrayal as the only journalist with integrity, while his colleagues are portrayed as sell-outs. It appears to be a somewhat distorted view that is hard to accept. Crowe is less physically imposing here, but he is just as commanding and more subtle than usual. He often presses his forefinger against his nose to adjust his glasses. Pacino is forceful without the histrionics. Christopher Plummer is masterly as an arrogant Mike Wallace. With Philip Baker Hall as Don Hewitt, Diane Venora, Lindsay Crouse, Debi Mazar, Bruce McGill, Michael Gambon, Stephen Tobolowsky, Gina Gershon.

Michael Mann's directional skill is at some of his best in The Insider.
